newsitem.title: USA: Midwest Express Q3 results set record.
newsitem.headline: Midwest Express Q3 results set record.

text.p: Midwest Express Holdings Inc said Wednesday it reported its best-ever results in the third quarter, with record earnings for its Midwest Express Airlines and Astral Aviation, which does business as Skyway Airlines.

"We experienced record passenger traffic and continued strong revenue yields in the third quarter," said Timothy Hoeksema, chairman, said in a statement. "Traffic increased 13 percent and capacity 17 percent. And equally important, our yield increased 6 percent system-wide."
Midwest Express earned $1.31 in the third quarter, up from $0.93 a year ago after $0.13 in non-recurring costs.
Increased aircraft fuel costs, Midwest Express' second largest expense , cut operating income $2.3 million in the quarter and $6.0 million year-to-date.

The company's cost per available seat mile increased 3.8 percent quarter over quarter, primarily as a result of the increased fuel costs. However, the cost per seat mile was four percent lower than in the second quarter, mainly due to efficiencies realized through increased capacity.
In September, Midwest Express Airlines placed an additional jet aircraft into scheduled service, resulting in new nonstop service between Kansas City and Boston, and between Kansas City and Omaha.
Also, Astral Aviation added nonstop turboprop service between Kansas City and Omaha, the company said.
Midwest Express said its 23rd jet will enter service in late 1996 and will be used in place of aircraft going off-line for routine heavy maintenance.
Three DC-9 aircraft acquired this year will go into service during 1997 after maintenance and other work. Midwest Express did not say how it will utilize those aircraft.
